return

JavaScript Basics

Table of Contents

  • Introduction
  • Comments
  • Values & Types
  • Variables
  • Arithmetic
  • Control Flow
  • Truthy and Falsy
  • Semicolons
  • Summary

Introduction

JavaScript is the programming language of the web. It is the most used programming language among software developers today.

JavaScript is a high-level , dynamic , prototype-based , interpreted programming language. It is well suited to object-oriented and functional programming styles.

JavaScript was developed by Brendan Eich at Netscape in 1995. It was designed to add interactivity to websites, something HTML couldn't do alone. In 1996, JavaScript was standardized by ECMA (European Computer Manufacturers Association), resulting in the language's official name, ECMAScript. Over the years, its use-cases have expanded beyond the browser with environments like Node.js (see my deeper dive into Node.js here )

Most commonly, the execution environment for JavaScript is the web browser. You can run JavaScript code inside your DevTools in the web browser itself via the console.

Comments

JavaScript has two types of comments: single-line & multi-line. 

// This is a single-line comment

/*
* This is a
* multi-line
* comment
*/

Values & Types

JavaScript types can be divided into two categories:

  1. Primitive types - numbers, strings, booleans.
  2. Object types - collection of properties where each property has a name and value. 
let num = 123; // Number
let str = "Hello World"; // String

let bool = true; // Boolean

Variables

Before you can use a variable or constant, it must be declared. This is done with let & const . The let keyword is used to declare a variable and can be reassigned. The const keyword is used to declare a constant, and must be initialized with a value.

JavaScript variables are untyped - meaning you don't have to explicitly state the type of data when it is declared. If an initial value is not specified, the value is undefined until a value is assigned. 

// Declaring an untyped variable
let data;

// Let declaration (can be reassigned)
let age = 30;

// Const declaration (cannot be reassigned)
const pi = 3.14;

Arithmetic

JavaScript supports the standard arithmetic operations: addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division, along with modulus (remainder), increment and decrement. 

let a = 10;
let b = 3;

console.log(a + b); // Addition: 13
console.log(a - b); // Subtraction: 7
console.log(a * b); // Multiplication: 30
console.log(a / b); // Division: ~3.33
console.log(a % b); // Modulus: 1
console.log(a++); // Increment: 11
console.log(a--); // Decrement: 9

Control Flow

JavaScript has several control flow statements including if-else, switch, for, while, and do-while. 

// if-else
let a = 5;
let b = 10;
if (a > b) {
    console.log('a is greater than b');
} else {
    console.log('b is greater than a');
}

// switch
let fruit = "apple";
switch(fruit) {
    case "banana":
        console.log("I like bananas.");
        break;
    case "apple":
        console.log("I like apples.");
        break;
    default:
        console.log("I like all fruits.");
}

// for loop
for (let i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
    console.log(i);
}

// while loop
let i = 0;
while (i < 10) {
    console.log(i);
    i++;
}

// do-while loop
let j = 0;
do {
    console.log(j);
    j++;
} while (j < 10);

Truthy and Falsy

In JavaScript, a value is either "truthy" or "falsy". A truthy value is a value that is considered true when encountered in a Boolean context. A falsy value is a value that is considered false when encountered in a Boolean context.

JavaScript uses type coercion in Boolean contexts, which are basically places where it expects a Boolean true/false value.

There are only six falsy values in JavaScript:

  1. false
  2. 0 and -0
  3. "" (empty string)
  4. null
  5. undefined
  6. NaN

All other values, including all objects (and arrays) are truthy, meaning they will evaluate to true when placed in a Boolean context. 

if ([]) {
    console.log('This is truthy!');
}

if (0) {
    console.log('This will not be logged because 0 is falsy');
}

Semicolons

Semicolons are optional in JavaScript. However, it is good practice to use them to make the meaning of your code clear.

Summary

This note provides a fundamental overview of JavaScript, discussing its origins, nature, and core concepts.
